author: By Fortesa Latifi
title: For a Bride With Chronic Illness, a Wedding Cut Short
description: A woman, whose symptoms have made her infamous for the “Irish exit,” struggles to cope with the physical and emotional toll of trying to make it through her own celebration.
content: Last fall, my wedding day ended with me crying in my mother’s lap as my new husband held my hand, both of them assuring me I had done so well. All I had wanted was one spotless day.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joshua Barone
title: The Pains and Privileges of Staging Mozart’s ‘Don Giovanni’
description: Three artists preparing a new production of this classic at the Metropolitan Opera discuss what makes it so difficult yet satisfying.
content: There are operas that are challenging for their sheer technical demands — the density of Berg’s “Lulu” or the heroic immensity of Wagner epics. And then there are those that seem simple but are actually some of the most difficult.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabella Kwai
title: London’s Coronation Countdown: Travelers Arrive, Others Flee
description: While hundreds of thousands are expected to arrive in London ahead of the crowning of King Charles III, others are making plans to get out of town.
content: Robin Higgins Horwitz knew she wanted to be in London for the coronation of King Charles III, even before the event was announced for May 6. An avid British history buff, her interest in the royal family sparked as a teenager watching the 1981 wedding of then Prince Charles and Diana, Princess of Wales.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Choe Sang-Hun
title: After Warmth From Biden, South Korea’s Leader Faces a Different Tune at Home
description: President Yoon Suk Yeol’s foreign policy, aligning his country more closely with Washington and Tokyo, has polarized his country. And critics say he has won little to show for it.
content: President Yoon Suk Yeol went to Washington to reset South Korean diplomacy by drawing closer to the United States and taking a larger role on the international stage. If the warmth of his reception there was the gauge of success, he did well.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maya King
title: South Carolina Democrats Elect First Black Woman to Run State Party
description: Christale Spain won with the support of the party establishment, including Representative James E. Clyburn.
content: South Carolina Democrats elected Christale Spain, the former executive director of the state Democratic Party, as state party chair at their convention on Saturday. She ran with the backing of the party’s top brass, including Representative James E. Clyburn, and will be the first Black woman to lead the state party.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Schwirtz and David Guttenfelder
title: Life in Ukraine’s Trenches: Gearing Up for a Spring Offensive
description: With fighting in the eastern Donbas region settling into a bloody stalemate, a patch of the Zaporizhzhia region of southeastern Ukraine could prove to be the war’s next big theater.
content: In a thicket of trees between two vast farm fields, a plywood trapdoor built into the forest floor opened to reveal stairs leading underground.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ian Austen
title: A Once-Promising Green Energy Technology Hits a Roadblock
description: Tidal power turbines operating on the Bay of Fundy in Nova Scotia were suspended after the company running them was unable to get a permit to continue testing.
content: As part of The Times’s coverage of the global climate summit last year, I wrote an article about a project in Nova Scotia designed to create renewable electricity from the Bay of Fundy’s exceptional tides. Now, a regulatory roadblock means that the pilot project may soon shut down.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maria Jimenez Moya, Eduardo Medina and Jesus Jiménez
title: After a Neighbor’s Complaint, Gunman Kills Five People in Texas Home
description: The attack on Friday night started after a man was asked by neighbors to stop shooting in his yard, the authorities said. The gunman remained at large.
content: CLEVELAND, Texas — Francisco Oropeza was firing his gun in his yard again on Friday night, rattling off loud bangs that were keeping Wilson Garcia’s baby awake.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: The Lagerfeld Looks That Defined a Career (and Remade Fashion)
description: How best to understand the designer whose 64-year career is the basis for the 2023 Met Gala and Costume Institute exhibition? Just look at the clothes.
content: Through talent, longevity and sheer productivity, it is possible that Karl Lagerfeld did more than any other designer to shape the look of the latter 20th century and the early 21st century. Across more than six decades, five different brands (three at the same time) and numerous collaborations, he flooded the zone from Paris to Dallas to Shanghai, dressing Hollywood, the haute and the high street.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ernesto Londoño
title: Minnesota Votes to Legalize Marijuana as Democrats Press Liberal Policies
description: Democrats, who took control in St. Paul, have moved forward with a long list of plans, including expanding abortion rights and offering driver’s licenses for undocumented immigrants.
content: MINNEAPOLIS — Minnesota lawmakers on Friday voted to legalize recreational use of marijuana, the latest in a string of policy moves to the left after Democrats took full control of the Statehouse after nine years of divided government.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maya King and Reid J. Epstein
title: As Biden Runs Again, Black Voters’ Frustration Bubbles
description: In interviews, Black voters, organizers and elected officials pointed to what some saw as unkept promises — raising questions about the enthusiasm of Democrats’ most loyal voters.
content: President Biden began his re-election campaign this week vowing to “finish the job” he started in 2021. No one wants him to do that more than Black voters.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Editorial Board
title: Biden Can Close the Extrajudicial Prison at Guantánamo
description: The U.S. naval base on Cuba has become synonymous with American shame.
content: Last week, Said bin Brahim bin Umran Bakush was released from detention at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, and returned to Algeria, his home country. Suspected of being a low-level fighter for Al Qaeda, at age 52 he was in his 21st year of detention in the prison, had no charges filed against him and stopped speaking to lawyers about five years ago. Mr. Bakush’s release leaves 30 men, of the 780 held there over the years since 2002, still imprisoned at the U.S. naval base whose name has become synonymous with American shame.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sara Murphy
title: When Friends Are Your Primary Concern in Making a Will
description: For many people who feel closer to friends than family, estate planning can require special considerations.
content: I turn 43 in May. In recent years, I’ve taken over managing my mother’s finances, which will all go to me when she passes. My father has split his assets evenly between me and my half sister. Designating their heirs was easy and conventional: Leave everything to the kids. A perpetually single, childless woman like me? Convention offers no road map.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Penelope Green
title: A Daughter of a Warhol Superstar Tells Her Story at Last
description: After an unruly childhood in the Chelsea Hotel and online fame as a yoga parodist, Alexandra Auder writes an ode to bohemian Manhattan and her singular mother, Viva.
content: PHILADELPHIA — Alexandra Auder was almost born in the lobby of the Chelsea Hotel, then a febrile bohemian enclave on Manhattan’s West 23rd Street, but her mother, Viva, a Warhol superstar, managed to make it to the hospital as the staff egged her on. “A girl! I want a girl!” a bellman declared, helping her into a taxi.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Lyall
title: Murderous Husbands and Creepy Kids
description: Our thrillers columnist on three new nail-biters.
content: What happened to Jane Larkin, a young suburban mother who vanished in 1975? Her haunting absence forms the center of William Landay’s ALL THAT IS MINE I CARRY WITH ME (Bantam, 320 pp., $28.99), a gripping if occasionally uneven psychological excavation of a family’s past.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michelle Goldberg
title: This Is What the Right-Wing Takeover of a Progressive College Looks Like
description: The slow and steady dismantling of New College of Florida.
content: SARASOTA, Fla. — When I first met Matthew Lepinski, the faculty chair of New College of Florida, he was willing to give the right-wingers sent to remake his embattled progressive public school a chance.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Euan Ward
title: Under the Hollywood Spotlight, a Fading Welsh Town Is Reborn
description: A former industrial hub, Wrexham had long been in decline. Now, it’s reviving as the globally famous star of a reality series about its once forlorn soccer team’s rejuvenation.
content: In the Welsh language, the virtually untranslatable word “hiraeth” (pronounced here-ayeth) describes a blend of nostalgia and longing for a time that can never be recreated.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By McKenna Oxenden
title: Digitized Silhouette Portraits Shed Light on 19th-Century Life
description: The album’s fragile pages were laced with arsenic, so the Smithsonian’s National Portrait Gallery put the images online last month. Curators have since identified more than 1,000 of the 1,800 subjects.
content: More than two decades ago, the Smithsonian’s National Portrait Gallery acquired a 19th-century album filled with nearly 2,000 silhouette portraits, including those of two former presidents.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Hard Truths About Organ Transplants: The Often Harrowing Aftermath
description: Transplant recipients, doctors and others react to a guest essay by a dying woman with a donor heart.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scott Cacciola
title: Forcing Game 7, the Youthful Kings Make Golden State Look ‘a Little Tired’
description: Sacramento, which hasn’t won a playoff series in 19 seasons, is using its youth to its advantage against the defending champions.
content: SAN FRANCISCO — In an otherwise quiet moment before the Sacramento Kings took the court for their most important playoff game in nearly two decades, Harrison Barnes gathered his teammates around him and urged them to focus on the task at hand so they could take the series back to Sacramento.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Janice Y.K. Lee
title: ‘The Half Moon’ Has a Powerful Pull
description: On its surface, Mary Beth Keane’s new novel is about a faltering marriage. But it’s also about small moments that matter.
content: The experience of reading Mary Beth Keane’s absorbing new novel, “The Half Moon,” feels — pleasantly — like breathing, or maybe just living. When we meet Malcolm and Jess Gephardt, their marriage is in a sludgy stage of dissolution, a casualty of hasty decisions, imprudent judgments and exhaustion. Malcolm mans his slowly failing bar, the Half Moon, in their hometown, Gillam, unable and unwilling to give up on his dream, and Jess has left him to go live temporarily with a friend in nearby New York City.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennie Coughlin
title: He Lost His Legs in the War in Ukraine, but Not His Will to Run
description: Artem Moroz survived an attack on his unit, but he was not sure he would stand again. Then a movie about the 2013 Boston Marathon bombing inspired a new goal.
content: Artem Moroz’s four-mile race in Central Park in Manhattan this month didn’t go as planned.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick McGeehan
title: 4 Parking Garages Ordered Evacuated After Deadly Collapse in Manhattan
description: In a sweep of dozens of garages, engineers found unsafe conditions including deteriorated steel beams and cracked or crumbling concrete.
content: In the wake of a deadly collapse of a parking garage in Lower Manhattan last week, New York City officials found structural problems at four other garages so dangerous they ordered the buildings at least partially vacated.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren McCarthy
title: Ticketmaster Finds Itself in a Royal Mess Over Coronation Concert
description: Some British residents said they received misleading emails suggesting they had secured free tickets to the concert for the coronation of King Charles III at Windsor Castle.
content: At five minutes past noon on Tuesday, Ticketmaster sent Joe Holmes and many others in Britain an email: “Congratulations, you have been successful in the ballot” for two tickets to King Charles’s coronation concert.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Kirsch
title: ‘Are You There God? It’s Me, Margaret’ Arrives
description: The books we read when we’re young help shape the adults we become in ways we don’t always grasp.
content: If you ask any kids who grew up reading Judy Blume, they’ll tell you precisely what they learned from each of Blume’s books; which taboo rites of passage each book introduced; probably even where they were, physically and developmentally, when they first stumbled on this information. They might very well remember the precise page number of the paperback that was passed around middle school on which the most eye-opening passages appeared.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jacob Bernstein
title: Time Magazine Celebrates as Web Pioneers Wonder What’s Next
description: A tale of two Manhattan media bashes. One was a star-studded, made-for-TV event. The other was attended by journalists who have been put through the digital wringer.
content: On Thursday, a week after BuzzFeed closed its Pulitzer Prize-winning news division and laid off 15 percent of its staff, Jonah Peretti, the company’s chief executive, predicted in a memo to his remaining employees that the future of the media business lay in “huge cultural moments” and “fun.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Walther
title: Consider This the Next Time Your Beer Betrays You
description: All major companies now have roughly the same politics.
content: A considerable number of Americans appear to believe that Bud Light, a beer owned since 2008 by the Belgian multinational corporation Anheuser-Busch InBev, stands for a set of values that does not include transgenderism. This became clear this month after the transgender activist Dylan Mulvaney posted on Instagram an informal video advertisement for Bud Light that featured a photo of a promotional tallboy can sporting an image of Ms. Mulvaney’s face.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dennis Overbye
title: Back Then, Baby Galaxies. Next, a Super-Mega Galactic Cluster?
description: The Webb telescope has spotted some of the oldest known collections of stars. They may have a very bright future.
content: Like basketball scouts discovering a nimble, super-tall teenager, astronomers using the James Webb Space Telescope reported recently that they had identified a small, captivating group of baby galaxies near the dawn of time. These galaxies, the scientists say, could well grow into one of the biggest conglomerations of mass in the universe, a vast cluster of thousands of galaxies and trillions of stars.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eve Washington, Josh Katz and Tom Giratikanon
title: Top 10 Hardest and Easiest Spelling Bee Words, April 22-28
description: No spoilers: “Balding” and “time” were easiest to find in recent puzzles, while “libidinal” was lacking.
content: This week, libidinal — which means “relating to sexual desire” — was the word least found by players of Spelling Bee, while balding was the most found. (We’ll leave the aging jokes to you.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Mueller
title: Scientist Revisits Data on Raccoon Dogs and Covid, Stressing the Unknowns
description: After analyzing genetic data swabbed from a Wuhan market in early 2020, a virologist said it was unclear if animals for sale there had been infected.
content: A new study of genetic data from a market in Wuhan, China, said the data did not support the case that the pandemic had started with illegally traded animals, touching off fresh debate about samples that other scientists see as critical pieces of the puzzle of how the coronavirus reached humans.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Judith Warner
title: What’s It Like to Have a Baby These Days?
description: In “Birth,” Rebecca Grant examines the experience of childbirth in the United States through the experiences of three women.
content: The French existentialist philosopher Simone de Beauvoir provides an epigraph for “Birth,” Rebecca Grant’s exploration of pregnancy and childbirth in the United States. “Pregnancy is above all a drama playing itself out inside the woman between her and herself,” Beauvoir wrote in “The Second Sex” (1949). “She experiences it both as an enrichment and a mutilation.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jamelle Bouie
title: A Sinister New Page in the Republican Playbook
description: Recent tactics constitute an attack on the idea of representation itself.
content: On Tuesday, I wrote about the Republican effort to limit the reach and scope of initiatives and referendums as another instance of the party’s war on majority rule. One thing I wanted to include, but couldn’t quite integrate into the structure of the column, was a point about the recent use of legislative expulsion to punish Democratic lawmakers who dissent from or challenge Republican majorities.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul McAdory
title: Line Dancing Toward Euphoria
description: Stud Country, a queer line dancing and two-step class from Los Angeles, made a rollicking return to New York on a recent Monday.
content: On the night of April 17, a crowd of 20- and 30-somethings, many of them queer, packed into Georgia Room, a Georgia O’Keeffe-inspired nightclub at the Freehand Hotel in Manhattan. They were there to drink and dance, but they hadn’t paid $25 each to grind or freestyle. They came to line dance.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonah E. Bromwich, Benjamin Weiser and Lola Fadulu
title: Rape Case Places Trump in Legal Jeopardy. Politically, He’s Thriving.
description: The former president’s new campaign is rolling unimpeded under the spotlights. In quiet courtrooms, he faces more serious threats.
content: During E. Jean Carroll’s first day on the witness stand, her lawyer asked what had brought her to a federal courtroom in Manhattan.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ronda Kaysen
title: The Ice Cream Truck Across the Street Is Making Way Too Much Noise
description: Truck operators, like all food vendors in the city, must be licensed and permitted, and comply with various rules and regulations.
content: Q: We live in a co-op building opposite a small park on East 77th Street. An ice cream truck parks at the entrance to the park, right near our apartment, for 12 hours a day, with a diesel generator running the entire time. We cannot open our windows or sit on our balcony because of the noise and air pollution. Is there anything that can be done? Many of our neighbors complain about it. We’ve contacted 311, our City Council member, the police and the ice cream truck owner. Our efforts have accomplished nothing. What can be done?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Santora and Victoria Kim
title: Large Fire Burns at Crimea Fuel Depot After Suspected Drone Attack
description: A Russian-installed local official blamed the blaze on “enemy drones.” Ukraine, which typically maintains a policy of strategic ambiguity about strikes in Crimea, did not claim responsibility.
content: KYIV, Ukraine — A drone attack on a fuel depot in the city of Sevastopol in Russian-occupied Crimea set off an enormous fire early Saturday, a Russian official said, in the latest assault on a peninsula key to Moscow’s war effort.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neelam Bohra and Coral Davenport
title: New California Rule Would Ban Sale of Diesel Trucks by 2036
description: The regulation, which must be approved by the federal government, is the latest in a series of ambitious moves by the state to cut planet-warming pollution from vehicles.
content: California state regulators approved on Friday a ban on the sale of new big rigs and buses that run on diesel by 2036, going beyond the federal government in issuing requirements to reduce emissions and setting the stage for other states to follow suit.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ron Lieber
title: Some Colleges Offer Quotes of Competitors’ Prices. Be Wary.
description: Schools may try to guess other campuses you’re considering and provide a list of their prices. They may not be accurate.
content: Every year, a new crop of innocents arrive in the marketplace for an undergraduate degree. Very quickly, they get an education in some unwritten rules.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maureen Dowd
title: Requiem for the Newsroom
description: Nobody’s going to make a movie about reporters at home with their cursors.
content: WASHINGTON — I don’t want this to be one of those pieces that bangs on about how things used to be better, and they’ll never be as good again.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Cry of Amazement
description: This Saturday puzzle by David Steinberg is for the 1 percent (those of us who solve Saturday puzzles).
content: SATURDAY PUZZLE — The geometry of this grid really scratches the itch for intricacy, if you’re familiar with that urge. The two span entries split the puzzle neatly into quarters, but that was lost on me until I solved both entries and found that they were playfully related in meaning. Then their visual connection swam into focus through the smaller stair-steps of fill, which I found pleasing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Megan Specia
title: London’s Other Royals, the ‘Pearlies,’ Keep Alive Cockney Customs
description: The Pearly Kings and Queens, known for their button-festooned costumes, preserve a charitable tradition that began in the Victorian era and became a symbol of the city’s working-class culture.
content: The kings and queens of London’s lesser-known royal family gathered outside a church in Covent Garden on a recent Sunday afternoon dressed in their sparkly finery.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Rogers
title: Press Freedom! Celebrities! (Also, the President.)
description: President Biden, who gets out of town most weekends, will attend the White House Correspondents’ Association dinner on Saturday evening.
content: WASHINGTON — The White House Correspondents’ Association dinner is an annual celebration of the importance of the First Amendment. And, you know, Chrissy Teigen might show up.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Fandos
title: George Santos, Instead of Shrinking From the Spotlight, Steps Into It
description: Mr. Santos seems to be testing whether his notoriety will translate into a form of celebrity, if not eventual acceptance.
content: WASHINGTON — As he strode into a bar packed with margarita-sipping young Republicans here the other night, Representative George Santos of New York looked like a man who had finally gotten what he had always wanted.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gregory Schmidt
title: Home Buyers Are Eager but Sellers Are Scarce, Creating ‘Real Gridlock’
description: Homeowners with low-rate mortgages are delaying the decision to sell until market conditions change.
content: The housing market typically comes to life in spring, when buyers emerge in the warmer weather. This year, the market appears stuck in a deep freeze, and the biggest culprit is a lack of sellers, housing experts say.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Ismay
title: Army Grounds Nonessential Flights After 2 Helicopter Crashes
description: Aviation squadrons will have to complete more training before resuming flights after the deaths of 12 soldiers in midair collisions within a month.
content: WASHINGTON — The U.S. Army said on Friday that it was grounding all Army flights except those needed for critical missions until aviation squadrons complete required training after two deadly helicopter crashes in a month.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren McCarthy
title: Man Who Crashed Into Teens After Doorbell Prank Is Found Guilty of Murder
description: Anurag Chandra was convicted of first-degree murder and attempted murder after crashing his car into another vehicle, killing three teenagers and injuring three others.
content: A California man who crashed into a car of six teenagers after they played a doorbell ditch prank at his home in 2020 was convicted of murder on Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Haruka Aoki
title: The Acrobatics of Viewing Art
description: After spending an afternoon in a crowded gallery, an artist discovers there’s more to view than just what’s on display.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesse McKinley
title: Today’s Wordle Review
description: Our columnist reviews the day’s puzzle. Warning: Contains spoilers!
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This article contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: SATURDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tiffany Hsu
title: A Towering, Terrifying Demon Horse Isn’t Even the Weirdest Part
description: The Denver airport is a magnet for conspiracy theories — and a case study in the line between mass delusion and fun.
content: Equine art lives in many airports: Seattle and San Francisco have bronze horses shaped like driftwood, Central Illinois has wire horses suspended from the ceiling, Tucson has a winged horse and Barcelona has a burly horse.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Wilson Wong
title: Why Are More Men Getting Perms?
description: The modern male perm is softer, more natural and has taken off, thanks to K-pop and TikTok.
content: The modern men’s perm is loud for a hairstyle so soft. On TikTok, the hashtag #menperm, referring to one of the latest hair trends to be born from the app, has garnered more than 20.7 million views.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Tanier
title: Who Won, and Who Lost, in the 2023 N.F.L. Draft
description: Philadelphia, Detroit and Green Bay all had their reasons for making the picks they did. Here’s what we learned in the draft aftermath.
content: The Philadelphia Eagles’ general manager, Howie Roseman, hustled like a pool shark. The Detroit Lions’ coach, Dan Campbell, displayed his rugged individualism. And the Green Bay Packers, playing the role of a merry divorcé post-Aaron Rodgers trade, dallied with new playmakers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elian Peltier
title: Sudan’s Conflict Ignites Fears of Civil War in Darfur
description: The fragile peace that quieted years of genocidal violence in Darfur is at risk again.
content: After a cease-fire faltered in Sudan’s capital, two weeks of fighting between the country’s army and a paramilitary group have reignited violence in Darfur, a region scarred by two decades of genocidal conflict that left as many as 300,000 people dead.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noam Scheiber and John Koblin
title: Will a Chatbot Write the Next ‘Succession’?
description: As labor contract negotiations heat up in Hollywood, unions representing writers and actors seek limits on artificial intelligence.
content: When the union representing Hollywood writers laid out its list of objectives for contract negotiations with studios this spring, it included familiar language on compensation, which the writers say has either stagnated or dropped amid an explosion of new shows.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ross Douthat
title: Can the Meritocracy Survive Without the SAT?
description: Institutions may settle for a new type of elitism.
content: The rapid abandonment of the SAT and ACT as requirements for college admissions, to the point where more than 80 percent of four-year colleges didn’t require a standardized test for admission in the coming fall, is a milestone in the history of the modern meritocracy. What remains to be seen is whether it’s a marker on the road to the meritocracy’s demise.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: April 29, 2023
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, April 29, 2023.
content: An article on Friday about a prominent business group in Harlem that has filed suit against the state’s plan to open a cannabis dispensary there misstated the name of Gov. Kathy Hochul’s chief of staff. It is Stacy Lynch, not Stacey Lynch.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren Hirsch, Maureen Farrell and Jeanna Smialek
title: Regulators Prepare to Seize and Sell First Republic
description: JPMorgan, PNC and Bank of America are said to be interested in acquiring the troubled lender after it is seized by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation.
content: Federal regulators were racing over the weekend to seize and sell the troubled First Republic Bank before financial markets open on Monday, according to people with knowledge of the matter, in a bid to put an end to a banking crisis that began last month with the collapse of Silicon Valley Bank.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesse McKinley, Grace Ashford and Hurubie Meko
title: New York Will Toughen Contentious Bail Law to Give Judges More Discretion
description: State leaders agree to eliminate a provision that requires judges to prescribe the “least restrictive” means to ensure defendants return to court.
content: ALBANY, N.Y. — It was just four years ago that New York’s Democratic lawmakers celebrated a new law that eliminated bail for most misdemeanors and nonviolent felonies and, at the time, seemingly added a measure of new justice to a system long faulted for pre-emptively punishing the poor.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Grace Ashford
title: Gov. Hochul Gets a Budget Deal, but No Signature Win
description: The budget deal contained a series of hard-fought wins for the governor, but left her without a grand policy achievement to trumpet.
content: ALBANY, N.Y. — It was around dinner time on Thursday, with many New York State lawmakers already heading home to their districts, when Gov. Kathy Hochul dropped a budget bombshell: Roughly four weeks past the deadline, she and legislative leaders had reached a tentative deal.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Name Dropping
description: It’s not what you know; it’s Lewis Rothlein and Jeff Chen’s second Sunday collaboration.
content: Jump to: Tricky Clues | Today’s Theme
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Lauren Hirsch and Sarah Kessler
title: Should uninsured deposits get a warning label?
description: In the wake of bank collapses, some have called for the F.D.I.C. to guarantee all deposits. But there may be a more strategic solution.
content: How do we avoid the next run on a bank?
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Hochul Arrives at Budget Deal With With List Largely Unfilled
description: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, April 29, 2023.
content: “It really is still three men in a room, just two happen to be women. That has not changed at all.”
source.name: The New York Times
